title: 109_hr3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". The Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, authorized by the Flood Control Act of 1944, aimed to promote economic development in the US. The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, a key part of the program, impacted the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe by flooding their land and causing economic and cultural damage. Congress has provided compensation to some Indian tribes affected by the project. The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project flooded the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, causing economic and cultural damage. Congress compensated the tribe, but additional compensation was later provided through the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act created the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund to compensate tribe members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act established a fund to compensate tribe members for land lost to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to ensure fair compensation for land lost to the Oahe Dam and Reservation project. The Act emphasizes that the United States did not adequately compensate the Tribe and member landowners for the acquired land. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to define "member landowner" as a Tribe member who owned land on the reservation acquired by the United States. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to define "member landowner" as a Tribe member who owned land on the reservation acquired by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The term "power program" refers to the program under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is also amended regarding funding by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit 25 percent of the amount from the power program into the Fund annually. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit 25 percent of the amount from the power program annually, with the total amount deposited equaling a specified sum at the end of the fiscal year. This sum includes a fixed amount and interest earned on that amount if invested as of October 1, 2001. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit 25 percent of the amount from the power program annually. Interest and earnings are determined by applying the Lehman Government Bond Index. Amendments include changes in fiscal year start dates and redesignation of paragraphs. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to deposit 25 percent of the power program amount annually, with interest determined by the Lehman Government Bond Index. Amendments involve changes in fiscal year start dates and redesignation of paragraphs for additional compensation to member landowners in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to deposit 25 percent of the power program amount annually, with interest determined by the Lehman Government Bond Index. Amendments involve changes in fiscal year start dates and redesignation of paragraphs for additional compensation to member landowners in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Secretary of the Interior shall provide records to assist the Tribe in processing claims of heirs of member landowners for land acquired by the United States for the project. The eligibility of the Tribe for certain programs and services is expanded to include member landowners.
